metadata.title: Let's build GPT: from scratch, in code, spelled out
metadata.author: Andrej Karpathy

nodes.name: Introduction to AI
nodes.description: An overview of Artificial Intelligence, its historical context, key milestones, and the distinction between different intellectual traditions and views on AI.

nodes.name: AI as Agents View
nodes.description: The perspective of AI as seeking to create or recreate human-like intelligence, focusing on capabilities such as perception, language, motor control, knowledge, reasoning, and learning from experience.

nodes.name: AI as Tools View
nodes.description: The perspective of AI as technology used to benefit society and augment human capabilities, often solving problems that humans don't naturally perform, rather than replicating human intelligence directly.

nodes.name: Ethical Considerations in AI
nodes.description: Discussion of critical issues arising from AI deployment, including adversarial examples (security vulnerabilities), and societal biases (fairness) embedded in models due to training data.

nodes.name: Modeling, Inference, and Learning Paradigm
nodes.description: A structured approach to solving complex AI problems by breaking them down into three conceptual pillars: building a simplified model, asking questions (inference), and using data to fit model parameters (learning).

nodes.name: Modeling
nodes.description: The process of taking a complex real-world problem and creating a mathematically precise, simplified representation (a model) that can be processed by a computer.

nodes.name: Inference
nodes.description: The process of asking questions about a given model and computing answers efficiently. This involves using algorithms to derive insights or predictions from the model.

nodes.name: Learning
nodes.description: The process of specifying a model's structure without all its parameters (a 'skeleton') and then using data along with a generic learning algorithm to automatically determine or 'fit' those parameters.

nodes.name: Machine Learning (General Concept)
nodes.description: A foundational building block of AI where systems learn from data to build models that can generalize to new, unseen experiences, shifting complexity from explicit code to data.

nodes.name: Reflex Models
nodes.description: AI models that operate based on a fixed set of computations, directly mapping input to output without internal state or explicit planning, emphasizing speed and direct response (e.g., linear classifiers, shallow neural networks).

nodes.name: State-Based Models
nodes.description: AI models that represent the world as a set of discrete states and possible actions that transition between these states, enabling agents to plan and think ahead, often used in games, robotics, and navigation.

nodes.name: Search Problems
nodes.description: A type of state-based model where the agent has full control and aims to find an optimal sequence of actions (a path) to achieve a goal, typically minimizing cost or maximizing reward.

nodes.name: Adversarial Games
nodes.description: A specialized type of state-based model where an agent plays against an opponent who is actively trying to counter its moves, requiring strategies that account for intelligent adversaries.

nodes.name: Variable-Based Models
nodes.description: AI models where solutions are represented as assignments to individual variables under a set of constraints, suitable for problems where the order of operations is not critical, like Sudoku or scheduling.

nodes.name: Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSPs)
nodes.description: A class of variable-based models characterized by hard constraints that variables must satisfy, focusing on finding a valid assignment of values to variables that meets all specified conditions.

nodes.name: Bayesian Networks
nodes.description: Variable-based models that represent probabilistic relationships (soft dependencies) between variables, allowing for inference and tracking in situations with uncertainty, such as car tracking with sensor readings.

nodes.name: Logic-Based AI
nodes.description: AI systems capable of digesting heterogeneous information, representing it symbolically, and performing reasoning to answer questions and infer new facts, exhibiting a deeper level of understanding compared to purely data-driven systems.

nodes.name: Optimization (General Concept)
nodes.description: The general process of finding the 'best' possible solution or configuration (e.g., a path, a set of parameters) that minimizes or maximizes an objective function.

nodes.name: Discrete Optimization
nodes.description: A type of optimization focused on finding the best discrete object from a finite or countably infinite set of possibilities, such as finding the shortest path in a graph.

nodes.name: Dynamic Programming
nodes.description: A powerful algorithmic technique for solving complex discrete optimization problems by breaking them down into simpler, overlapping subproblems and storing the results of these subproblems to avoid redundant computations.

nodes.name: Recurrences (in Dynamic Programming)
nodes.description: The formulation of a complex problem's solution in terms of solutions to smaller instances of the same problem, serving as the mathematical backbone for dynamic programming algorithms.

nodes.name: Memoization
nodes.description: An optimization technique used in dynamic programming to cache the results of expensive function calls and return the cached result when the same inputs occur again, thereby reducing redundant computations.

nodes.name: Edit Distance Problem
nodes.description: A classic discrete optimization problem solved using dynamic programming, involving finding the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, substitutions) required to transform one string into another.

nodes.name: Continuous Optimization
nodes.description: A type of optimization that seeks to find the best vector of real numbers (e.g., model parameters) that minimizes or maximizes a continuous objective function.

nodes.name: Regression
nodes.description: A machine learning technique for predicting a continuous output variable based on one or more input variables, often involving fitting a line or curve to data points.

nodes.name: Least Squares
nodes.description: A common principle used in regression to quantify the 'badness' of a model's fit by summing the squared differences between predicted and actual values, aiming to minimize this sum.

nodes.name: Derivative and Gradient
nodes.description: Mathematical concepts representing the rate of change of a function. The derivative applies to single-variable functions, while the gradient generalizes this to multi-variable functions, indicating the direction of the steepest ascent.

nodes.name: Gradient Descent
nodes.description: An iterative continuous optimization algorithm that finds the minimum of an objective function by repeatedly taking steps proportional to the negative of the gradient of the function at the current point.

nodes.name: Step Size (Learning Rate)
nodes.description: A hyperparameter in gradient descent that controls the magnitude of the steps taken in the direction opposite to the gradient, influencing the speed and stability of convergence to a minimum.
